Calling Tyrion insecure, traumatized, and an incel isn't a take, it is literally who he is. Call it reductionist, but what three words would you use to describe him? You'd be hard-pressed to find words that explain him better than those. I get you don't like the connotation, but it's definitely accurate. 

And no one is upset about people who are just explaining why Tyrion did what he did. That's not the problem. As said multiple times, the problem is people using any discussion about Shae's murder to talk about how much they enjoy seeing a woman get murdered for humiliating a man. If you can see why Tyrion doing what he did was wrong, then you're not the problem and there is no need to be offended.
I thought I was at r/asoiafcirclejerk and was so confused why everyone was saying no instead of adding more into the joke

>the problem is people using any discussion about Shae's murder to talk about how much they enjoy seeing a woman get murdered for humiliating a man. 

You should genuinely be banned for this unless you're able to produce quotes from people saying this. This is just a gross thing to accuse people of with zero evidence backing you up. The subreddit shouldn't have to deal with bullies.

Pointing out that someone's relationship with their long term prostitute vs. their barber is a lot different does not mean I think Shae isn't capable of causing the execution of Tyrion or Sansa. What I'm saying is how you feel about your barber committing perjury in a trial against you is not the same as the person you slept with damn near everyday for months or years. Sex work is not an equivalent service to hair cutting. If Tyrion's barber told on him he wouldnt be anywhere near as mad at them as he was with Shae. Anyone who refused to testify could've been tortured or killed, and Tyrion knew that. If he was in that situation he would've saved his own ass too.

Additionally, while She's testimony did help convict him, he was already going to be convicted once the trial started whether she testified or not. And yes she was given money for testifying, but if you think she could've just said no and walked away you are being naive. That is coercion.

I'm not making up what you said, I'm just making the barber do the same shit Shae did, and one of the things in her situation was coercion. You can claim all day she wasn't coerced, but she was coerced. That happened. Think what you want but I'm not arguing with you about facts just because you don't understand the definition. And I don't agree with you that committing perjury in a trial is the same thing as helping kill someone. It just isn't. If it was, a lot more people who've committed perjury in death row or life imprisonment trials would be getting charged with attempted murder. Lying at a trial is not the same thing as physically killing someone yourself. It just isn't. 

And yes! I still think killing the barber is unnecessary, cruel, and evil. It is not morally justified to kill someone because they humiliated you or committed perjury. It is understandable why Tyrion did that, but it isn't justifiable. It is not good or right. It is unnecessary, cruel, and evil. That is my OPINION. It's okay if you don't share it. As I said before, if you're not getting joy for seeing a woman murdered then you're not the fucking problem.

"Whatever he did was right. He was also right when he said "I should have let Stannis kill you all". I relate to Tyrion so much and the hate he feels towards those that mocked him and turned on him is absolutely justified."

-

This person enjoyed Shae's death. I'm not going to add their username but it's from this thread so you can find it. 

-

"Insecurities as a man"

He just got mocked, villainized and sentenced to death in a speech that ended with her stating that she forced him to say words that were originally meant to comfort him, now meant to disgrace him.

I can imagine many would snap for instance if their partner complemented them on their "aquiline features" or "regal disposition" in quiet moments of comfort, and then turned it on them in a criminal trial by calling them a "vulture looking freak with a weak stance and features". While Tyrion probably does feel this makes him less of a man, I don't think the fear that your insecurities *as a person* being turned on you by the people you care about at the worst possible time is unique to any race, creed or sex.

-

I don't think this person actually enjoyed Shae's death, but the attempt to justify killing someone by saying many people would snap in that situation is concerning. Just about everyone would be upset, but strangling someone to death over it is NOT normal nor is it justifiable. Everyone has experience humiliation in their lives and most of us do not kill the person who humiliated us. So I was bothered by the implication here, but I'm not saying this commenter actually thinks killing people is okay. 

-

These two comments are why I commented. There are other comments that are iffy. But this isn't the only thread I've ever read where people thought it was justifiable to kill Shae. I've seen a lot of gross shit like that on Facebook specifically. 🤷‍♀️ As a female fan I see men say horrible things about female characters all the time, and it wears you down.

So no one who said they enjoyed seeing women being killed by men? That was your claim right?

>killing someone so you can continue to escape is NOT A GOOD OR JUSTIFIABLE REASON. It being self defense DOES NOT MAKE IT A GOOD OR JUSTIFIABLE ACTION. All it does is EXPLAIN IT. It is UNNECESSARY, CRUEL, AND EVIL to kill people because you are trying to escape.

Remember when you claimed killing out of self-preservation while trying to escape an unjust execution was evil?

I don't believe you're a woman considering some of the wild things you've said about women in past posts, but hey who knows. You seem to really think it's cool that Sansa would be put to death.

No one in this thread explicitly said that but I can read between the lines. Again I have seen other people say things that indicated they also enjoyed seeing a woman killed for humiliating a man. Believe what you want. 

Yes that's exactly what I said, that killing out of self preservation because you're escaping is evil. You are taking someone else's life who is just doing their job so you can escape. It's understandable but it is not justifiable or good. 

Also, where do you get off trying to tell me you don't think I'm a woman? What do I need to do, post a pic of my vagina? Jesus, dude. Since you've been reading my past posts go read my many comments throughout Reddit talking about my experience as a woman. All this complaining about bullying and you say some shit like that to me? You are an enormous hypocrite.

>No one in this thread explicitly said that but I can read between the lines.

You genuinely can't. 

>What do I need to do, post a pic of my vagina?

Please stop being creepy.

Stop trying to invalidate me and then acting like you're an innocent victim of bullying on this thread. 

I genuinely can read between the lines, unlike you.

You actually do.

You can yap on about human nature and go ask Micky Mouse what his policy for ruling Disneyland will be, the comparison between the average man versus Aragorn who descended from a mythic people who live on Atlantis was never fair. His wife is a bloody elf who were made by the gods.

GRRM chose to approach his story with the average man doing the best they can, Tolkien was writing of high fantasy with exceptional races. Aragorn is a good king because he’s better, it’s that simple, people who tries to compare him to the average man and say the average man wouldn’t do that is the precise sort of pedantry I’m pointing out

This is my bad. When you said this

>Except Aragorn also spent 80 years travelling Middle Earth, his moral and character was thoroughly tested throughout his journey, we know he is good man. 

it sounded a lot like yapping about human nature. If your point was "Martin can only be questioning tax policy (explicitly not what he was saying) and the gritty bookkeeping because Aragorn is so divinely better through the genetics in his veins that the only possible response one could level at a narrative is about the specifics of tax policy, anything else is pedantry" then I apologize for underestimating how blinkered a view of writing you have, keep up the good fight.
I accept your apology dipshit, keep your head down next time.

Is it Jon killing her or her becoming evil or both? Because book Dany literally just made the active,willing, and informed choice to be evil. 

I sincerely read your article and I hate shitty cliches like it describes. I hate that Jon and Dany had a relationship at all romantically, that was too cliche for me. I hate that the story had Jon kill her and that another woman's death was used to propegate a man's arc. That's another cliche I hate. But I love evil Dany, if she keeps her agency. No madness  cliche bullshit. Just a person whose arc naturally led them to its conclusion. 

After reading your article I see how grrm has deconstructed that trope with folks like Sansa and Cat (even though it flies over morons heads quite a bit). Anywho. Sorry if I came off aggressive or anything, you don't seem to enjoy this convox so thanks for the chat!

Do you have any quotes for your claims? Because there is only three times "passionate" even gets mentioned in the whole series and none of those relate to Visenya:

>Her marriage, never **passionate**, had become a mummer’s farce by 54 AC. “And not an entertaining one,” Lady Alayne Royce observed.

\- F&B, about Rhaena and Androw Farman

>I suppose I came to love her after a fashion, though our relations were dutiful rather than **passionate**. Three times she miscarried while trying to give me an heir. The last time she never recovered. She died not long after."

\- ACoK, about Jorah's first wife

>Jaime had never seen her more **passionate**. Every time he went to sleep, she woke him again.

\- ASoS, about Cersei and Jaime

I can't really be bothered to check the rest of your claims, but it might help if you stopped reading the wiki and started reading the books.
I have read the books thank u all the descriptions are from fire and blood and the world of ice and fire. So please put your bitchy remarks aside and maybe not comment if it is not helpful

Last (and some might say the least) of the peoples of the North are the swamp-dwellers of the Neck, known as crannogmen for the floating islands on which they raise their halls and hovels. **A small, sly people** (some say they are small in stature because they intermarried with the children of the forest, **but more likely it results from inadequate nourishment**, for grains do not flourish amidst the fens and swamps and salt marshes of the Neck, and the crannogmen subsist largely upon a diet of fish, frogs, and lizards), they are quite secretive, preferring to keep to themselves. -written by GRRM, TWOIAF

Definitely not a crisis of ascension because her cute hubby decided to fuck and marry (in show, so far) a girl who had serious power (daughter of a head noble lord, yada yada) backing her, at a time when her own children already faced racist prejudice! Duh. I mean it's definitely not like in the past some lovely Targeryens thought they'd remarry only to end their entire lineage in severe crisis, both times! (Maegor and Viserys 1) Plus it's not like the girl in question was already engaged to ANOTHER noble lord btw, who also happened to have to ties to the throne! (Robert Baratheon was indeed the grandson of Targaryen woman, I forgot the name) It's definitely not like there was already tensions in the court due to a current ruler being cuckoo ass crazy! And it's not as if she had any self respect at all, despite being the only Non Targaryen woman who was a princess in her own right! You're so right!

As for Dany, she also thinks that her father wasn't a madman, and everyone else simply just got up in arms against him and killed him. She's supposed to be an unreliable narrator, as is everyone else. So to say that her vision may be a proof that Elia was happy is the same as saying "Well Dany says her father was a mad man so it's true." It's why unreliable narrators exist

Retrospectively I can see why some are interpreting this as a shit-post, but no, I did intend this question genuinely. I think it’s a relatively straightforward and appropriate question to ask given the context and George’s obvious left leaning. George did make progress on TWoW during Trump’s first term, but mainly because he had nothing better to do during Covid. There’s no Covid this time. I expect George will be stewing in political ire, and I don’t think it’s a stretch to say this may affect his productivity. Give me your thoughts! How would Harris winning have changed the course of TWoW releasing, if at all?
